Sweeeeeeeettttt!!!!!!!1 I can't wait for this! Pardon the self advertising, but you should use my beautiful skybox in this series.

Thanks for the offer. I'll have a look, but I've got my own personal skybox, plus I've already made considerable headway in the game, as per usual, so... yeah, no skybox changes for me. Thanks again, though:)
I am very excited for you, and excited for the thread. I cannot wait until it comes out!
So excited! Cant wait!

ERMAHGERD

...yay!

Thanks for the offer. I'll have a look, but I've got my own personal skybox, plus I've already made considerable headway in the game, as per usual, so... yeah, no skybox changes for me. Thanks again, though:)

Just following on from this...

I tip my hat to you; that is a very nice skybox. However, my stance hasn't changed; I'm still using my own.

Ok, next item on the agenda...

So far, I'm standing at a 3-part prologue, and 8 proper chapters detailing everything up to the Minmus landing. It's going to be quite a long story. Release schedule will be one to two chapters per week, and I plan on releasing the first part of the prologue later today. I do have exams coming up in a few weeks, so the schedule may be a bit disrupted, but I plan to appease you with at least one chapter per week. For now though, we shall see...

Edited May 7, 2014 by RogueMason

-snippy-

I am quite literally bouncing with joy right now.

PROLOGUE Ã¢â‚¬â€œ PART 1

Five years have passed since the last Venturer mission, and in that time, there has been little on the front of manned planetary exploration. The Duna Recolonisation initiative has been proceeding smoothly, with a station now orbiting the red planet plus a new base facility on the surface. What many people donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t know is that there has been a vast amount of work ploughing ahead in secrecy. A meeting has been called to assemble the most senior staff and the most promising recruits. Jeb and co. are in the lounge chilling out just as Bill walks into the room.

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hey, Bill, over here!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ah, there he is. DidnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get lost, did you?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No, I didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t. It would be awkward if the navigator of multiple spaceships got lost in this complex.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Undoubtedly.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Anyway, GeneÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s just sent me to get you lot.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“For what, exactly?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve got a meeting, right now.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“A meeting? I havenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t been told anything about any meetings.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, me neither.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You pulling a fast one, Bill?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No, no, this is serious.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill looks up from the gang to the rest of the kerbonauts in the room.

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oi, you lot, he wants you too!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Sidman: Ã¢â‚¬Å“What? All of us?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t think weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re all gonna fit into that boardroom, BillÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No, weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re not all going to fit in the boardroom, which is why weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re going to the SPH. Now, come on!Ã¢â‚¬Â

A few murmurs began to resound along with the shuffling of feet as every kerbonaut in the room got up and filed out.

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Surely it would have been easier for him to haul his a** over here instead of making us all barge into the SPH? You know how the techies working on the SSTOs can get.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ugh, them and their precious spaceplanes. DonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get me wrong, I think spaceplanes are about the best method of getting to orbit, but those guysÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“SSTOs are tough things to build, Jeb. That said, theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve had a good run, recently, and there was that one they launched a few hours ago. Should make them less irritable.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I bl**dy hope so.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Come on, you guys, I donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t want to have to sit through another lecture from Gene about being late because you couldnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get off your backsides.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh, just us not getting off our backsides, eh?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah. In case you hadnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t noticed, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m sort of all over the place with teaching these new guys a thing or two about navigation in orbit, plus thereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s all the nasty PR stuff.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ã¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Exactly, now come along.Ã¢â‚¬Â

A few minutes later, in a fairly packed SPHÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hello? Testing, testingÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ *tap tap* Ah, alright, sorted. Right, youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re probably all wondering why IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve called you out here, so IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll get straight to it. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m assuming you all watched that spaceplane taking off earlier today?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, yeah, we saw it. What of it?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, it safely reached Kerbin orbit with fuel to spare, and obviously the guys at the SSTO department were pretty pleased with that.Ã¢â‚¬Â

The SSTO techies give a little wave from their corner at the back of the SPH.

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“SoÃ¢â‚¬Â¦?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t coming back down to Kerbin. Instead, weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re launching a tug very soon to meet up with it.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hold on, was this thing manned?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No, it wasnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t manned.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“But it had a cockpit?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s going to Laythe.Ã¢â‚¬Â

A few murmurs wind their way through the cluster of kerbals.

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“So, youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re sending an unmanned spaceplane to Laythe? Gene, you know IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve always wanted to go to Laythe, so whatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s going on? And why are there so many of us here?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“JebÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Be quiet, buddy.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ugh, alright then.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Now, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m sure you folks are also aware that the Venturer program is at an end, or so we told the public. What you guys donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t know is that weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve got thousands of people working right now to develop hardware and plan a mission that we thought impossible.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Random Kerbal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Land on the sun?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ã¢â‚¬Â¦No.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Random Kerbal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“AwwÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Sorry to disappoint, although I shouldnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t really have to say that seeing as this mission is huge in scope, and we need the best, which is why youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re all here. Not a single one of you can mention a word of this project outside of the KSC facility. WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be trialling everyone to see whoÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll fly this mission, and only 12 of you will be chosen.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Only 12 of us??Ã¢â‚¬Â

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Out of the hundred or so of you that are here, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d say 12 is a relatively small number, Jeb.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s still a lot of folks to put on a mission. This couldnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t beÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“If this is what I think it is, thenÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ well, I never thought IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d see it.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Looks like the A-team here guessed it. Welcome to the start of our grand tour.Ã¢â‚¬Â
Now this sounds interesting. You've picked a good time to begin too.

Now this sounds interesting. You've picked a good time to begin too.

It would appear that way, it seems, but I very highly doubt that I'll live up to the bar set by czokletmuss and his Grand Tour. Nevertheless, I'm putting everything I've got into it. We'll see how it turns out.

Hm. Iiiinteresting...

So is the RNG deciding the crew, or are the Big Four pretty much inevitable?

'Cause the Four are awesome.

I guess you're just going to have to wait for the next part of the prologue to find out

I do actually have a crew roster at the end of part 3, too, so you'll know who's flying on this epic mission, and what they're doing.

PROLOGUE Ã¢â‚¬â€œ PART 2

Several months after the announcementÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

In the astronaut complexÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“They sent the Tylo lander off to Jool, today.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh really? ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s good to hear. I just hope the thing works on that wretched moon.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“So you can get your rocks?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yep.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“And if it were to failÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Then not only would I be the first Kerbal to set foot on Tylo, but IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d be the first one stranded there, too. However, theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve run simulations, and it looks like it should perform just fine.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hmm.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: "You have to bear in mind that they are also sending a fusion-powered fuel tanker over there that will more likely than not have fuel remaining once we're through with it. I can always use that to help with the descent."

Cal: "I suppose you know what you're talking about, seeing as you're the engineer..."

Jeb walks in and plonks himself down into a chair opposite Lengas and Calwell.

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“If I were you, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d be more concerned about the Eve lander.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Uhh, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m not flying that one, remember?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh, rightÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ but still.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ã¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“WhatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s wrong with the design?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Designs. Plural. None of them are working.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“What?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, every simulation they run ends up with not enough structural support or a lack of fuel or thrust. I told them to put more boosters on, but noooooo, theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re too Ã¢â‚¬ËœsensibleÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ for that.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“UhÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ huhÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Anyway, now theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re contacting some airship company to come and help out with the lander. Blasphemy, if you ask me.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Balloons? ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢sÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s actually brilliant. It would make Eve ascents much easier.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Pff, nothing like rocket engines to get you somewhere.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“But clearly theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re not going to be working too well on that purple hell-hole of a planet, are they?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Sadly. Oh well, I wonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t be flying the Eve lander either, so it makes no difference to me.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Have they decided who will?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m not sure, but we are still a few years out from the launch of the mission. Plenty of time to make considerations, and hey, maybe some new guys will join the space program and end up with us.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“How many spots are left to fill?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, let's see... thereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s me, Bill, and Bob, plus Lengas here. Then we just got Macwise because he came out top in med school. I think Buzz might be with us, too, so thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s 6 spots taken so far, 6 left to fill.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, Buzz is definitely with us. I was with him when Gene gave him the news. Pardon the pun, but he was buzzing.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Very punny, Lengas. Anyway, there you go, Cal. 6 spots.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Actually, err, you might want to make that 7 spots taken upÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Huh?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I got picked this morning. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m on the mission.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh, nice!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, congrats!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“ThanksÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ logistics and astrophysics, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m in charge of. Should prove interesting.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Indeed. Anyway, welcome aboard! You flown any other missions yet?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be taking a Swiftwind III for a spin in a weekÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s time, but IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve already clocked about a month in the simulator.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, I think youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be just fine, then. Astrophysics and logistics, thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s definitely a big job. Mess up one of my fuel tankers, and IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll throw you out the airlock.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh, yeah, sure you will.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Heh.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Nah, like I said, youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be alright. Now, anyone for coffee or something?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Sounds good. Let me just grab my jacket.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Over one year laterÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

Now, I know what you're thinking. "Why have you already posted the next part of the prologue? You gave us your schedule just a few days ago and it said bla bla bla..."

Well, forget the schedule. I'll just post chapters when I feel like it. However, it's probably going to be one chapter every two days now, most likely. That's sort of a schedule still, but oh well.

Also, due to the installation of the Environmental Enhancement mod (only for the clouds; I got rid of the city lights) partway through the mission, you'll notice some differences in what the planets look like (Eve will very suddenly change between chapters...). I also upgraded my skybox partway through, too; it now has visible nebulae plus brighter stars of varying colour. Same basis, with that blue galactic plane, but more detail. I quite like it

Coooool.

So the Big Four do appear tob e on the crew, or did I miss something?

They already talk about throwing people out the airlock Only joking, but still.

I hope they will have a better tour than czo's poor guys

Coooool.

So the Big Four do appear tob e on the crew, or did I miss something?

You missed nothing. The Big Four are there

They already talk about throwing people out the airlock Only joking, but still.

I hope they will have a better tour than czo's poor guys

I hope so, too

Uh oh... It seems the assassins are back (again), because I had somebody trying to imitate (online) me when I came in, and that person nearly managed to get me (thank goodness for the .22 being easily accessible).

Wait, what? A .22 rifle? You weren't... if I'm reading this right... are you alright? Nothing too bad happened? If I've got this horribly mixed up, please say, because it sounds to me like someone got into your house...

On a lighter note, next chapter tomorrow (hopefully)

Asassins! Aaah!

So if I have this right, you're using the (fusion-powered?) ENT-053-A to do the tour?

Hopefully less lethal than the czo-tour.

PROLOGUE Ã¢â‚¬â€œ PART 3

A few weeks after the Tylo lander reached JoolÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“So, they went with that stupid balloon design after all, did they?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It minimised the fuel needed for the mission, and itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s safer. Besides, you arenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t flying it, remember? Buzz will be doing that.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m just saying, if the tech guys had added more boosters, the old design would have worked.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I doubt it.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Sidman: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Structural whatnot, eh Lengas?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Indeed. We surely donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t need to tell you that one again, Jeb.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ã¢â‚¬Â¦Just because the two of you are engineers, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll leave it.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Sidman: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Cool. Anyway, Gene? Can I talk to you outside?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Uh, sure.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Sid and Gene walk outside, their chatter audible before the door shut behind them.

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“So, where do we stand?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“The cruiser is being built as we speak. In a few months, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be ready to fly. TheyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re strapping one of those fusion engines to the back, like the one from LonestarÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ remember that?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I remember trying to hold the reactor together with duct tape after that encounter we had. Toughest engineering challenge IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d ever faced, not least because five other lives were on the lineÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Man, that was a long time ago now.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I almost miss those days.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I miss them awfully, sometimes. Being the first Kerbal to walk on MunÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ that was awesome. I canÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t wait to go back there again.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill, Bob, and Buzz walk in.

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Folks.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hey.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Jeb.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Buzz.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“What are we talking about?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“The good old days.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Although IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve been around a lot longer than you have, Lengas.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Nevertheless, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve seen my fair share of spaceflight.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Not as much as me.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve practically shared the last couple of missions together, except for Venturer.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hey Jeb, have you ever actually walked on the surface of Duna, like good old Lengas here?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“IÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ no, I havenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢tÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ oh my kod, I havenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t done that!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“SomehowÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s settled; IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m landing on Duna. Give me that crew roster, would you?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Uh, sureÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok, letÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s see hereÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ ah, there we go, Duna landingÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ huh, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m already down for it. No need to alter it. HmmÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“WouldnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t that have been effectively criminal, Jeb, if you did alter it?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Which is why itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a good thing I didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t need to.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hmm.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m hungry. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m going to get lunch.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Actually, me too. HavenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t eaten today. Too much training, too much looking at transfer windowsÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s mind-blowing, the amount of calculations IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve had to do, lately.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“FooooodÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve already eaten. See you guys later.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hey, come with us, donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t just lurk around here all day.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m going home, for now. ThereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢sÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ stuff that I need to sort out. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m going to be gone for a while, so I may as well sort it out while I can.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh, alright then. Catch you later.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, bye guys.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Sid and Gene shuffle past the folks who just left.

Asassins! Aaah!

So if I have this right, you're using the (fusion-powered?) ENT-053-A to do the tour?

Hopefully less lethal than the czo-tour.

ENT-051-A. But yes, a ship by the name of Enterprise has finally succeeded on my save (the other two blew up...).

And I do hope it's much less lethal than the czo-tour, but of course, anything can happen...
I bet aliens are at Vulcos.

Wait, what? A .22 rifle? You weren't... if I'm reading this right... are you alright? Nothing too bad happened? If I've got this horribly mixed up, please say, because it sounds to me like someone got into your house...

Yeah, a (minor) case of home invasion. Didn't trip the alarm system because he slipped through the windows leading into the basement (which are quite small, mind you). Also, I was more just pointing the gun at him to get him out of the house, since a .22 longrifle is only really good for target practice and not much else (Also, my dad keeps the ammo in a secret location. Have to find out where he's keeping it one of these days.).
